item.title: Forensic after deleting VMs
item.dc:creator: linuxer
item.description:
Hello. I am using Kicksecure and Whonix on a virtual machine. Usually, I use live mode. If I delete these virtual machines, what level of danger exists in case of forensic examination? Or do these metadata not pose any danger? I understand that the best option would be to use Kicksecure-host in live mode, but I am interested in your opinion on virtual machines. Disk of course encrypted. There are many opinions on this topic. But you are the best security experts and I am very interested in your opinion. I think that the metadata in log does not pose a threat, otherwise you would not created Whonix and Kicksecure as virtual machines. But your answer is very important to me. Thank you

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic

item.title: Clock / Time is OFF
item.dc:creator: proicroizellesa
item.description:
I just did a fresh install of Kicksecure onto a fresh QubesOS 4.2.4 install using the debian-12-xfce template that ships with QubesOS.

The clock time for every Kicksecure templateVM and appVM is off. Nothing is in sync. All my other TemplateVM and AppVMs whether it is debian-12-xfce or Fedora-41-xfce are perfectly in sync.

Can anyone help tell me what is going on and how to fix it?

Here is sample output running “timedatectl status” command in a template and appVM

Shouldn’t it be in sync with system clock ?

timedatectl
Local time: Fri 2025-04-25 22:05:50 EDT
Universal time: Sat 2025-04-26 02:05:50 UTC
RTC time: n/a
Time zone: America/New_York (EDT, -0400)
System clock synchronized: no
NTP service: n/a
RTC in local TZ: no

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic

item.title: How to enable optical drive in kicksecure?
item.dc:creator: motionsuspended10
item.description:
I tried out the steps in this guide [SOLVED] Are Optical Drives disabled in KS?

But it didnt work, i might have disabled the UDF filesystem when editing the /etc/modprobe.d/30_security-misc_disable.conf

currently it is written like this: install udf /usr/bin/disabled-filesys-by-security-misc

idk if that means it is enabled or disabled. if it is disabled, is putting comments back onto the line all you have to do to enable? i have a feeling you have to remove the file “disabled-filesys-by-security-misc” but i figured i should ask here before trying anything.

all help is appreciated. the optical drive im using is the asus zen drive U9M and has worked out of the box on my laptop running Parrot OS.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic

Thank you for your work

item.title: How to use zulucrypt in USER Session?
item.dc:creator: linuxer
item.description:
Hello. How to use zulucrypt in USER mode / USER live mode? I received an important encrypted secret steganographic container in messenger, but I could not open it due to sudo restrictions. I need to reboot, decrypt file, and then load again in USER mode / live mode to respond to interlocutor. This will be inconvenient (this can be a confidential important conversation where time is crucial - for example, if it is related to investigative journalism). What would you recommend in this case? Installing zulucrypt in Podman or Distrobox?

ps Live mode SYSMAINT is very good for viewing encrypted containers and do not save secret session to disk, when you are not limited by time

5 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: How to use zulucrypt in USER Session?

item.title: LIVE mode SYSMAINT
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Patrick, does it make sense to limit live mode for increased isolation in user-sysmaint-split, given that disk writing is limited? Live mode is very convenient for testing packages, new programs before installing in PERSISTENT mode. Often I try to install some program, but during installation, I encounter dependency problems, library version issues… as a result, package either doesn’t work or can disappoint me. And then it is very convenient to reboot. Rather than deleting everything I just installed + no traces of such experiments are left on disk

7 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic

A very simple privilege escalation hat lets me access the LUKS password from system memory. WTF? I wanted to try Kicksecure because I saw that it would eventually become Whonix-Host. Is this is a bug?

Read full topic

item.title: Kicksecure vs Qubes (Whonix)
item.dc:creator: dreaml3zz
item.description:
You can use Qubes OS the secure OS together with Whonix (anonymity). You can use Kicksecure the security by default OS with Whonix too through VirtualBox.

How should an user who is looking for security and anonymity decide between those operating systems?

The main advantage of Qubes OS is its isolated design. In combination with Whonix you have a gateway which enforces all traffic from all VMs going through Tor.

But you might use Kicksecure as your OS exclusively to start your VirtualBox instance and use Whonix from there for all your work or offline VMs. Kicksecure OS updates would go through Tor by default.

What are the drawbacks in such a setup for using Kicksecure compared with Qubes OS?

8 posts - 4 participants

Read full topic

item.title: [SOLVED] Are Optical Drives disabled in KS?
item.dc:creator: obtrustive
item.description:
I morphed my Debian into Kicksecure on an old Macbook. Before, the optical drive worked fine, now it’s not recognized at all (“eject” and “lsblk” don’t list it).
My understanding is that the kernel KS uses is the same as Debian, but I also found that some kernel drivers a blocklisted for security reasons (such as firewire because it would enable known exploits).
The problem is that I rely on the optical drive. Is there any way to enable it?

Edit: I found this: /etc/modprobe.d/30_security-misc_disable.conf
Any idea which one is needed for and Apple MacBook2,1 SuperDrive?

SOLVED: by commenting out these lines:
blacklist cdrom
blacklist sr_mod

in:
/etc/modprobe.d/30_security-misc_blacklist.conf

EDIT:
Also had to allow the udf filesystem.

1 post - 1 participant

Read full topic
item.source: [SOLVED] Are Optical Drives disabled in KS?

item.title: Add VMs in /90overlay-root/overlay-mount.sh
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Hello. in 90overlay-root creates /live/image file system for live mode

#!/bin/sh

# make a read-only nfsroot writeable by using overlayfs
# the nfsroot is already mounted to $NEWROOT
# add the parameter rootovl to the kernel, to activate this feature

. /lib/dracut-lib.sh

if ! getargbool 0 rootovl ; then
    return
fi

modprobe overlay

# a little bit tuning
mount -o remount,nolock,noatime $NEWROOT

# Move root
# --move does not always work. Google >mount move "wrong fs"< for
#     details
mkdir -p /live/image
mount --bind $NEWROOT /live/image
umount $NEWROOT

# Create tmpfs
mkdir /cow
mount -n -t tmpfs -o mode=0755 tmpfs /cow
mkdir /cow/work /cow/rw

# Merge both to new Filesystem
mount -t overlay -o noatime,lowerdir=/live/image,upperdir=/cow/rw,workdir=/cow/work,default_permissions overlay $NEWROOT

# Let filesystems survive pivot
mkdir -p $NEWROOT/live/cow
mkdir -p $NEWROOT/live/image
mount --bind /cow/rw $NEWROOT/live/cow
umount /cow
mount --bind /live/image $NEWROOT/live/image
umount /live/image

is it possible to add a mount and launch virtual disk /var/lib/libvirt/images/debian.qcow2 (file itself is in /live/image) that it is launched in flows without consumption of additional memory? it will make a kicksecure a fantastically secure system (much cooler than qubes). live mode is perfectly launched by live-ISO, but how to avoid a load on memory with an already installed system, as is done with podman containers? solving this problem of memory load will help strengthen anti-forensicism. I use live mode every day, but even 32g of memory is not enough for working with VMs

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic

item.title: Hello, thank you, and a question about Secure Boot
item.dc:creator: spirit_of_solitude
item.description:
Hello lovely gentlemen, before I get going here I want to say a huge THANK YOU for selflessly automating so many good ideas in one place.

I’ve been unceremoniously digging into your wiki and general documentation, beginning (of course!) with a paradigm of Self Help

I’m in the process of migrating from GRUB to Systemd-Boot (formerly Gummiboot) and while the port has gone well, the kernel flag:

efi=disable_early_pci_dma

Works in GRUB, but prevents booting in systemd-boot. Before I go blaming Mr. Poettering for his crimes against humanity (I jest) I wonder if the very intelligent people in this community - with years more experience in this platform than I - may have any thoughts on why this might be.

Thank you very much for any insight, time, or just your thoughts.

PS: If you have any thoughts on UKI (Unified Kernel Images) and TPM bindings, I think I have a working layout but if perhaps there are gotchas to consider, or - and this is my greater fear - by switchinig out GRUB I may remove some hardening you have provided, I would certainly like to maintain all of that, and I would love a heads-up if I have wandered into a security minefield in my experimentations. Thanks.

2 posts - 2 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Hello, thank you, and a question about Secure Boot

item.title: Problem with sdwdate
item.dc:creator: sam
item.description:
Hello. I have some problems with sdwdate

● sdwdate.service - Secure Distributed Web Date
Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/sdwdate.service; enabled; preset: enabled)
Active: activating (auto-restart) (Result: core-dump) since Thu 2025-02-27; 3s ago
Invocation: 6242d938293f4a918c975dbc10cce343
Docs: sdwdate: Secure Distributed Web Date
Process: 9338 ExecStart=/usr/libexec/sdwdate/sdwdate (code=dumped, signal=SYS)
Main PID: 9338 (code=dumped, signal=SYS)
Mem peak: 2.1M
CPU: 39ms

  • set -e
  • true ‘INFO /usr/bin/sdwdate-log-viewer: START’
  • /bin/journalctl --boot --output cat -n 10000 -f _SYSTEMD_UNIT=qubes-sync-time.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=qubes-sync-time.timer + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=timesanitycheck.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=bootclockrandomization.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=sdwdate.service + _SYSTEMD_UNIT=whonix-firewall.service + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=suspend-pre + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=suspend-post + SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=anondate + _AUDIT_TYPE_NAME=SECCOMP
    Within minimum time ‘Tue Nov 5 00:00:00 UTC 2024’ and expiration timestamp ‘Tue May 17 10:00:00 UTC 2033’, ok.
    Boot Clock Randomization
    Boot Clock Randomization - Kicksecure
  • 104 185583560
    Changed time from … (1740642543.533538103)
    to … (1740642647.205970400).

item.title: Current Kicksecure Bullseye repo lacks hardened-malloc packages?
item.dc:creator: PrivacyTux
item.description:
Hello,

I wanted to update a VM that has not been updated for a while.
Unfortunately, the hardened-malloc package is no longer offered. Is there a reason for this and can the package be offered again via the Kicksecure Bullseye repo?

The hardened-malloc package is currently not available in any Bullseye repo, not in Stable, Stable Proposed, Testers, nor in Developers.

Last available version was:
hardened-malloc (0:12.5-1) unstable
Thu, 18 Jan 2024 14:09:29 +0000

Best regards

4 posts - 3 participants

Read full topic
item.source: Current Kicksecure Bullseye repo lacks hardened-malloc packages?
